Included in this group are some of the innovators of the form subway-pole, an adaptive
re-use of the New York transit infrastructure that has created a cultural space largely
occupied by young, African-American men. Through a shared interest in dance Gerard
& Kelly have developed a collaboration with several of the dancers, working together in
2015 as part of a residency at the New Museum in New York.
Liens vidéo:
In 2018, POLE will be re-created for presentations in the US and France, exploring
the productive notion of “post-nationalism” while interrogating the ways that racism,
colonialism, and heteronormatovity produce social relations in different contexts. POLE
incorporates a creative collaboration with Rio Uribe of the brand GYPSYSPORT who is
working with Gerard & Kelly to develop costumes and installation materials.

A 21 minute duet titled after Anselm Keifer’s 82 ft. long sculpture of undulating concrete and exposed rebar. In the work, I imagined time and space as palpable bodies and referenced oceanic tidal cycles (collapsing a full cycle, which lasts 24 hrs and 50 min, into a 21 min dance) as a way to frame how we witnessed time passing, making the space between two bodies visceral with intimacy and/or distance.
